profileText: A Representative from New Jersey; born in Woodstown, Salem County, N.J., March 30, 1822; attended Delaware College, Newark, Del., and Lafayette College, Easton, Pa.; was graduated from Princeton College in 1840 and from the medical department of the University of Pennsylvania at Philadelphia in 1843; commenced the practice of medicine in Woodstown, N.J.; member of the State house of assembly in 1854; elected as an Opposition Party candidate to the Thirty-fourth Congress and reelected as a Republican to the Thirty-fifth Congress (March 4, 1855-March 3, 1859); was not a candidate for renomination in 1858; resumed the practice of medicine in Woodstown, N.J., where he died on October 9, 1879; interment in the Baptist Cemetery.

researchRecord.name: In the Clawson Family Papers, 1800-1886, 1.35 cubic feet.
researchRecord.description: Represented in the collection are Isaiah Dunn Clawson and his wife, Martha. Included is an essay, "The Stability of our Government," by Isaiah Dunn Clawson, as well as printed matter relating to his terms in the New Jersey Assembly and Congress. The bulk of the correspondence is comprised of letters to family members about legal, business, social, political, and temperance matters. The collection includes documents such as judgment bonds and warrants, bills, promissory notes, receipts, claims, indentures, wills, mortgages, and bank account forms. A finding aid is available in the repository and online.

researchRecord.name: 1855-1871, approximately 110 items.
researchRecord.description: Correspondence, 1855-1871, consisting chiefly of letters received, but also including some drafts of letters sent. The letters from 1855 to 1860 relate largely to local New Jersey politics in Gloucester, Salem, Cumberland and Cape May counties. Additional letters request public documents or pertain to potential applicants to the U.S. military academies. After 1860, the letters increasingly deal with personal matters, especially finances, including the purchase of a cemetery monument from a firm in Philadelphia. Several letters pertain to the estate of Harriet R. Dowden, a black resident of Woodstown. A letter from a relative in Chester, South Carolina, dated September 1869, details financial hardship in the years immediately following the Civil War. Other letters pertain to the estate of Clawson's brother, evidently a Philadelphia judge.
